112592 S2468-8231(22)00478-3 10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112592 Scheme 1 The reaction pathway of xylose to furfural. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Schematic diagram of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs synthesis and catalytic xylose to furfural. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 (a) TEM images of WO3 NPs, (b) TEM images of WO3@mSiO2 NPs, (c) TEM images of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs, (d) Statistical diagram of particle size of WO3 NPs, (e) Statistical diagram of particle size of WO3@mSiO2 NPs, (f) Statistical diagram of particle size of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs, (g) EDS spectrum of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H, and the element mapping spectra of (h) Si, (i) S. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) The wide angle XRD image, (b) FT-IR spectra of WO3@mSiO2 NPs and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) N2 physisorption isotherms of WO3@mSiO2, (b) N2 physisorption isotherms of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H, (c) BJH pore size distribution of WO3@mSiO2 NPs, (d) BJH pore size distribution of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Py-FTIR spectrum of various samples at different temperatures, (a) WO3, (b) WO3@mSiO2, (c) WO3@mSiO2-SO3H. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Catalytic performance of various acidic catalysts. (b) Effect of catalyst dosage on catalytic performance. Reaction conditions: 0.10 g xylose, 0.05 g WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs, 2.5 mL water, 5 mL toluene,170°C, t=4 h. Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow Reaction and Separation Engineering of Shandong Province State Key Laboratory Base of Eco-Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao 266042 China A core-shell biacid catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H was prepared. Through the core-shell structure, an interface with internal and external spatial relationship was formed, which was used to synergistic catalyze the preparation of furfural from xylose. And the conversion of xylose was as high as 98.7% and the furfural yield was 70.1% at 170°C for 4 h in water-toluene mixture (1:2 v/v%). The research provided a case for the preparation of furfural from xylose catalyzed by sulfonated core-shell catalyst and provided more application prospects for core-shell catalysts in biomass conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Xylose WO3@mSiO2-SO3H Interface Synergy Furfural Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction With the scarcity of fossil energy and the requirements of global sustainable development, biomass is expected to replace fossil energy because of its cheap, rich, renewable and great potential in the production of valuable chemicals [1–4]. Furfural is a used biomass based platform molecule, which is widely applied in solvent, medicine, fuel and other fields [5–8]. In addition, it can produce valuable chemicals such as butyraldehyde and furoic acid. Efficient utilization of biomass to prepare furfural has always been a research hotspot [9]. Xylose was a rich monosaccharide in biomass. The molecular structure was not only simple and convenient to characterize, but also an ideal platform molecule to explore the catalytic mechanism of biomass conversion to high-value chemicals [10]. There were two main catalytic mechanisms for the preparation of furfural from xylose. When catalyst only provided Brønsted acid, xylose directly dehydrated to furfural (Scheme 1 R1). Compared with the catalytic pathway R1, when the catalyst contained both Lewis acid (LA) and Brønsted acid (BA), xylose was isomerized to xylulose by LA and dehydrated to furfural by BA [11], which had high efficiency of this pathway and the activation energy required for dehydration was low (Scheme 1 R2). At present, the catalysts for the preparation of furfural from xylose mainly included homogeneous catalysts (HMC) and heterogeneous catalysts (HTC). In industry, HMC (sulfuric acid and metal salt solution) were widely researched as their attractive price and superior activity. Compared with HMC, solid acid catalysts were studied for their advantages of easy recovery [12,13], less corrosive and environmentally friendly [14–16]. To maximize the activity of solid acid catalysts in processes involving multiple separate reactions, solid acid catalysts containing both BA and LA were required to catalyze synergistically the preparation of furfural from xylose. However, the furfural yield was only 53.4% when xylose was catalyzed by SO4 2−/ZrO2-Al2O3/SBA-15 at 160°C for 4 h [17]. This indicated that acid sites of supported catalyst arranged irregularly, and the same intermediate contacted the same active site for several times, which reduced the synergistic effect of acid sites and the reaction rate, and increased the number of side reaction products. Therefore, we enhanced the activity of the catalyst by constructing a specific spatial interface to regulate the distribution of active sites. Core-shell catalysts showed great potential in regulating the distribution of active sites and improving catalytic performance [18]. It prevented the agglomeration, leaching and destruction of active sites. At the same time, a stable interface at a specific spatial position was built by accurately regulated the distribution of different active centers on the shell and core according to spatial structure. After passing through the pores of the shell, the substrate orderly contacted with the core and shell to strengthen the synergistic effect of active centers and improve the yield of products. In this research, we prepared a new core-shell catalyst with sulfonated mesoporous silica as shell and tungsten trioxide as core. The -SO3H groups on the mesoporous silica shell provided Brønsted acid sites, and the WO3 core provided LA sites. Xylose was isomerized to xylulose under the action of WO3 (LA), and xylulose was dehydrated to furfural under the action of -SO3H (BA). The synergistic effect between BA and LA were improved by constructing an interface structure with specific spatial location. The experimental results and characterization showed that the core-shell catalyst had excellent catalytic efficiency on the production of furfural [19]. This work provided a successful case to degrade xylose to furfural by core-shell catalyst, and also provided a research basis for the various derivatives from biomass by core-shell catalyst. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, 99.5%) and Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%) were purchased from Sinopharm group. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99%) was obataind from aladdin. Tungsten hexachloride (WCl6, 99%) and ammonia (NH3·H2O, 25-28%) were bought from Macklin. D-(+)-Xylose (C5H10O5, 98%) and 3-mercaptopropyl trimethoxysilane (MPTMS, 97%) were received from Ron reagent. Methanol (CH3OH, 99.5%) and absolute ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.7%) were obtained from Tianjin Fuyu group. Toluene (C7H8, 99.5%) was bought from Yantai Far East Group, except as specified, distilled water and all other reagents were reagent grade to prepare aqueous solutions. 2.2 Preparation of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H As shown in Scheme 2 , WO3 nanospheres (NPs) were synthesized under mild conditions by hydrothermal method. Then, silica shell was coated on the surface of WO3 to synthesize WO3@mSiO2 NPs under the same reaction conditions by sol-gel method. Finally, -SH groups were grafted on silica shell surface by MPTMS, -SH groups were oxidized to -SO3H with H2O2 and acidified with sulfuric acid. Synthesis of WO3 NPs. Poured 100 mL distilled water into a flask containing 2.43 g CTAB and stirred at 28°C for 30 min. Next, 4 mL NH3·H2O and 4.64 g WCl6 were added, followed by ultrasound for 10 min and stirring for 4 h. After natural aged at natural temperature for 7 h, WO3 NPs were centrifuged four times with deionized water, then put it into the dryer and dried it at 80°C for 12 h. At last, the WO3 NPs were calcined to remove the template (CTAB) at 500°C for 3 h. Synthesis of WO3@mSiO2 NPs. 1.40 g WO3 and 2.24 g CTAB were added to a flask, 70 mL H2O and 280 mL C2H5OH were mixed, and 5 mL NH3·H2O were added after 60 min ultrasound. After stirring at 20°C for 2 h, slowly added 1 mL TEOS while stirring. Next, deionized water was added for three times after stirring for 8 h. Further, dried the mixture overnight at 80°C. Finally, the solid product was calcined at 500°C for 3 h to burn the template (CTAB) and get WO3@mSiO2 NPs. Synthesis of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs. 1.53 g WO3@mSiO2 and 191 mL H2O were added into the flask, heated the flask and flowed back the mixed liquid at 100°C for 3 h, and dried the mixture at 80°C after cooling. Then, 115 mL toluene was poured into the flask and distilled the mixture for 3 h. After natural cooling, 6.51 mL MPTMS was added into the flask while stirred at 20°C. After stirring 24 h, the solution was heated to boiling reflux for 3 h. Next, the solution was centrifuged and poured into in a petri dish, 30 mL CH2Cl2 was added into the petri dish to dry naturally for 24 h. Then, 20 mL methanol was mixed with above solid powder, following by ultrasound for 30 min, 4.40 mL H2O2 with a mass fraction of 35% was added into the solution and stirred for 12 h. Then, it was centrifuged with absolute ethanol. Finally, 50 mL H2SO4 (0.10 mol/L) was added into the mixture to acidify for 5 h, then centrifuged with water and absolute ethanol until there is no sulfuric acid present and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H core-shell catalyst was obtained by drying. 2.3 Characterization The catalyst pore diameter was measured by nitrogen adsorption isotherm by Micromeritics ASAP2460. The specific surface area of catalyst was obtained by Branauer-Emmet-Teller (BET). The pore parameters of catalyst were calculated by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH). Degassing pretreatment with N2 at degassing outlet, catalysts were analyzed at 90°C for 60 min and at 100°C for 240 min. The appearance of the catalyst was obtained by Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images taken by HT7800 at 80 kV. The element distribution of the catalyst was obtained by Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDX) images taken by HT7800 at 100 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Smartlab 9 kW advance powder X-ray Cu Kα radiation diffractometer. The Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-FTIR) spectrum was measured by Thermo Fisher Nicolet to determine the acid type of the catalyst. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with a Netzsch TG 209F3 instrument at a heating rate 10°C/min from room temperature to 800°C under N2 flow 80 mL/min. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the S content of the prepared smple (Thermo Fisher iCAP PRO). 2.4 Catalytic reaction The reaction of xylose to furfural was carried out in a 100 mL autoclave reactor with Teflon lining. The amount of 0.10 g xylose, 0.05 g WO3@mSiO2-SO3H, 2.50 mL H2O and 5 mL toluene were added into an autoclave. After sealing the autoclave, 2 MPa N2 was injected for 5-8 times to replace air. Then, the reactor heated to 170°C and kept for 4 h. After cooling to natural temperature, removed the supernatant from the autoclave for product analysis. The selectivity of furfural was detected by Shimadu GC-2010Pro gas chromatography (GC), and the chromatographic column was DB-5. The standard curves of different diluted concentrations of furfural were established by external standard method. The initial temperature was 60°C and holding 3 min, and the temperature was increased to 280°C at 8 °C/min for 15 min. H2 was used as carrier gas, the split ratio was 1:10. The conversion of xylose was detected by High Performance Liquid Chromatography equipped with differential detector and Bio-RadHPX-87H column. The standard curves of xylose were established by external standard method. The detection conditions were as follows: column temperature was 65°C and the mobile phase was dilute sulfuric acid (0.005 mol/L, 0.5 cm3/min). Eqs. (1)–(3) for calculating the conversion of xylose, the selectivity of furfural and furfural yield were as follows: (1) Conversion ( C . ) = Cxylos e in − Cxylos e out Cxylos e in (2) Selectivity of furfural ( S . ) = C Furfural Cxylos e in − Cxylos e out (3) Furfural yield = C . × S . Cxylosein was the initial xylose concentration added to the reactor, g/L; Cxyloseout was the xylose concentration in reactor after the reaction, g/L; CFurfural was the concentration of furfural in reactor after the reaction, g/L. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphological characteristics In order to determine the catalyst was core-shell morphology, we carried out TEM experiments. The TEM image of WO3 NPs was shown in Fig. 1 (a), WO3 had the morphological characteristics of nano polycrystalline structure. Fig. 1(d) revealed that the particle size of the WO3 was 30–60 nm. As shown in Fig. 1(b, e), WO3@mSiO2 was a clear core-shell structure, and the particle size was about 100 ± 4 nm. Through surface modification, -SO3H groups were introduced to the surface of mesoporous silica. Compared to Fig. 1(b, e) and Fig. 1(c, f), it can be concluded that the modification of -SO3H groups did not destroy the core-shell structure, which contained a solid core with a diameter of 60 ± 2 nm and a sulfonated silica shell with a diameter of 40 ± 2 nm. It was seen from Fig. 1(g–i) that Si and S elements were evenly distributed on the whole surface of NPs, which proved that -SO3H groups was successfully introduced on the surface of silica shell. This feature was conducive to the formation of Brønsted-Lewis interface with internal and external spatial relationship, so as to maximize the synergistic catalysis of BA-LA sites. To sum up, we have successfully prepared core-shell NPs. The sulfonated silica shell was successfully deposited on WO3 NPs, and the tightly connected structure formed the Brønsted-Lewis double acid interface. In order to prove that the catalyst took WO3 as the core and silica modified by -SO3H as the shell, wide-angle XRD and FT-IR were examined. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), wide angle XRD image showed that three peaks at 23.1°, 23.6° and 24.4°, which were attributed to 002 crystal plane, 020 crystal plane and 200 crystal plane of WO3 NPs respectively, and it coincided with the peak of amorphous silica. The peaks at 26.6°(120), 28.9°(112), 33.2°(022), 34.2°(202), 35.7°(320), 41.8°(221), 50.1°(140), 55.8°(402) were also the characteristic peaks of WO3 [20–22]. Moreover, it was obvious that the wide-angle XRD pattern changed little after sulfonation modification on the surface of mesoporous silica. It also proved that -SO3H groups did not destroy the crystallinity of internal WO3 (JCPDS 83-0950). Fig. 2(b) exhibited the FT-IR spectra of WO3@mSiO2 NPs and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs, and the test range was 4000–500 cm−1. The peak at 3500 cm−1 was resulted from the vibration peak of Si-OH, and the lattice water and hydroxyl bands of mesoporous silica distributed near 3450 cm−1 and 1609 cm−1. The stretching vibration peak of -SO3H was generally around 1060 cm−1, but this peak was difficult to identify because it overlapped with the asymmetric stretching vibration peak of Si-O-Si at 1073 cm−1. Besides, the broad band at 790 cm−1 was attributed to the symmetric stretching of Si-O-Si. Compared with the characteristic peak of WO3@mSiO2, the small peak of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H near 1400 cm−1 was the characteristic peak of S=O bond [23,24], which proved the existence of SO3H groups. In conclusion, the above two characterizations provided theoretical support for the successful preparation of core-shell structure with WO3 as core and sulfonated mesoporous silica as shell. The parameter of pores in the WO3@mSiO2 and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs were further confirmed from N2 physisorption. It was seen from Fig. 3 (a) and (b) that WO3@mSiO2 and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalysts had a typical type Ⅳ isotherm, which proved that WO3@mSiO2 and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalysts had a mesoporous structure [25]. In Fig. 3(c), the pore size of WO3@mSiO2 catalyst was 4 nm, which showed that the silica shell was mesoporous. In Fig. 3(d), after sulfonation modification, the WO3@mSiO2 surface still maintained a good mesoporous structure, which showed that sulfonation was not destroyed the mesoporous structure. In addition, the existence of pore structure made molecules act according to a specific path and reduce the side reactions between molecules. As illustrated in Table 1 , the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of WO3@mSiO2 were 693.5 m2 g−1, 3.8 nm and 0.42 cm3 g−1, and WO3@mSiO2-SO3H were 677.9 m2 g−1, 4.0 nm and 0.44 cm3 g−1. These results demonstrated that -SO3H groups were positioned inside the pores of silica shell or -SO3H groups caused some channels to collapse. Although the pore size of sulfonated catalysts become larger, it was still a mesoporous structure. The results were contributed to the contact between the acid sites and the subsequent raw materials. In addition, the diameter of xylose molecule was 0.68 nm [26]. After sulfonating, the pore size of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs was enough to allow substrates to enter and contact with WO3 active sites. 3.2 Acid characterization As shown in Fig. 4 , the type of acid sites and relative content of acid sites of catalyst were examined. Py-FTIR spectrum showed different pyridine absorption peaks between 1400 and 1700 cm−1. The band at 1635 cm−1 present on WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs was caused by the pyridine adsorbed on BA sites [27]. The sharp peak at 1602 cm−1 attributed to be hydrogen-bonded pyridine. Besides, WO3 and WO3@mSiO2 NPs had a peak at 1540 cm−1, which was attributed to pyridine adsorbed on strong BA sites. The band at 1490 cm−1 was assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on both BA sites and LA sites [28]. The LA sites on the WO3 and WO3@mSiO2 NPs were relatively high, which were provided by WO3. The content of BA sites were higher than LA sites on WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst, which were mainly provided by -SO3H groups on silica. When the temperature rose from 40°C to 150°C, the Brønsted acid strength and Lewis acid strength did not change much, which indicated that the temperature did not destroy the BA strength and LA strength obviously of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs for the reaction at about 150°C. Besides, Py-FTIR was a characterization method to analyze the properties and relative strength of surface acidic sites. The acid amount of WO3@mSiO2 was lower than that of WO3 in Table 2 , because the outer surface of WO3 was coated with mesoporous silica. Compared with WO3 NPs and WO3@mSiO2 NPs, the BA content of WO3@mSiO2-SO3H increased significantly, which proved that -SO3H was modified onto the surface and channels of mesoporous silica shell. This further confirmed -SO3H groups were successful introduced and formed a core-shell catalyst with WO3 as the core and sulfonated mesoporous silica as the shell. 3.3 Catalytic activity 3.3.1 Effect of various acidic catalysts and catalyst dosage In biomass conversion reaction, catalyst acted a decisive role in the yield of target products. It was seen from Fig. 5 (a) that the effect of catalysts with different acidic sites on furfural yield was investigated. Without adding any catalyst, the furfural yield was only 16.4%. The furfural yield increased to 33.9% when used catalyst mSiO2-SO3H, which mainly provided Brønsted acid sites [29]. When WO3 was used as catalyst, the introduction of LA sites made xylose first convert into xylulose to form furfural. Although the furfural yield was 40.4%, but the content of BA sites was low, and the intermediates were easy to diffuse repeatedly between acid sites, so compared to WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst, the furfural yield was lower. Besides, in Fig. 5(b), with the addition of catalyst from 0.03 g to 0.07 g, the conversion of xylose first increased and then remained basically unchanged. The furfural yield increased from 45.3% to 70.1%, and decreased to 60.6%. Research showed that with the increased of catalyst, the acid sites concentration increased, which not only promoted the generation of furfural, but also accelerated the decomposition, polymerization and other side reactions of furfural [30]. As shown in Scheme 3 (a), the WO3 core of the catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H provides LA sites, and the -SO3H group provides BA sites. By sulfonating -SO3H groups onto the silicon layer, a LA-BA interface can be formed at the edge of the core WO3, which could minimize the space distance between two acid sites and improve the synergistic effect. The intermediates formed on the WO3 (LA sites) could be immediately converted on the nearby -SO3H (BA sites), this process could avoid the repeated diffusion of intermediates between the two acid sites as much as possible [31], and the catalytic efficiency is high (23.3 mmol L−1 h−1, Table 3 ). Compared with the traditional supported catalyst WO3/mSiO2-SO3H, the intermediates can repeatedly diffused between geometrically separated Lewis/Brønsted acid sites (Scheme 3(b)), resulting in relatively low catalytic efficiency (17.7 mmol L−1 h−1, Table 3). 3.3.2 Effect of solvents In addition to catalysts, solvents also acted a decisive role in the yield of product. Under the same reaction conditions, water, methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)-water, cyclopentyl methyl ether (CPME)-water and toluene-water were used as solvents to discuss the effect on the furfural yield. As described in Fig. 6 , the catalytic effect was obtained with two-phase solvent was significantly higher than that obtained with single-phase solvent. When water was used as solvent, the furfural yield was only 29.5%. When two-phase solvent was used as solvent, the xylose conversion was over 94% and the furfural yield was over 55%, because the side reaction was serious in pure water system [32]. In addition, different types of organic solvents had different catalytic effects. Under the toluene-water solvent system, the furfural yield was 70.1%, which were higher than those under MIBK-water or CPME-water solvent systems in Fig. 6. Ketones and ethers had unsaturated carbon oxygen double bonds, which reacted with the aldehyde group in furfural molecule, resulting in the loss of furfural [33]. Therefore, toluene-water was used as solvent in this study, because xylose was soluble in water and insoluble in toluene, there was a strong interaction between furfural and water and the presence of water promoted the movement of xylose to the active centers of the catalyst [34]. In addition, water and toluene were high insoluble, so the furfural produced in the water was quickly extracted to toluene, avoiding by-reactions and improving the furfural yield. 3.3.3 Effect of time and temperature The effects of reaction time and reaction temperature on the conversion of xylose and the furfural yield were also examined, which was catalyzed by WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst in toluene-water biphasic solvent (2:1 v/v%). In Fig. 7 (a), with the progress of the reaction, the conversion of xylose increased from 88.1% to 96.9%, and the furfural yield increased first and then decreased. When the reaction time was too long, it would increase the contact time between each component and intermediate products, resulting in side reactions. As shown in Fig. 7(b), when the temperature rose from 150°C to 170°C, the conversion of xylose rosed from 95.9% to 98.7% and the furfural yield rosed from 61.6% to 70.1%. The furfural yield was 59.1% at 190°C, because furfural degraded and condensed at high temperature. In conclusion, the best reaction conditions for catalyzing xylose to furfural were as follows: 0.10 g xylose, 0.05 g WO3@mSiO2-SO3H NPs, 2.5 mL water, 5 mL toluene, T=170°C, t=4 h, and the optimum furfural yield was 70.1%. In addition, WO3@mSiO2-SO3H also used to catalyze hemicellulose, corncob and other substances (Table S1). Compared with similar core-shell catalysts, WO3@mSiO2-SO3H has low reaction conditions and high furfural yield. Compared with supported catalysts, the active centers are not easy to lose, and the furfural yield is similar or even higher (Table S2). The above results show that WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst has good catalytic performance. 3.4 Catalyst reusability In addition to excellent catalytic performance, stability was very important for the application of catalysts. Therefore, the reusability of the catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H was experimented. Before each cycle, the catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H needed to be centrifugation, washing and calcination, then impregnated with sulfuric acid, washed to neutral, and dried for use. Under the best reaction conditions, the WO3@mSiO2-SO3H was used as catalyst for 5 times and the furfural yield decreased by only 3% in Fig. 8 (a). The furfural yield decreased mainly due to the formation of some humus oligomers in the reaction process. In addition, after five times of recycling, it was seen from the TEM diagram that the WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst still maintained a good core-shell structure, which proved that the morphology of the catalyst did not change due to its participation in the reaction. It can be seen from Fig. 9 (a) that the weight loss before 200°C is attributed to the desorption of water or other volatile substances. The mass loss of the catalyst at 200–350°C may be attributed to the chemisorption of water, -SH, some oxygen-containing functional groups and some unstable -SO3H groups [35–37], which also indicates that the reaction temperature at 170°C will not cause the pyrolysis of -SO3H groups. The mass loss greater than 350°C may be due to elimination of water by condensation of surface silanols during calcination. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the mass loss at 200–800°C is mainly attributed to the condensation of silane alcohol and the unburned humus during the heating process [38,39]. As part of the -SO3H group was pyrolyzed during the calcination process, after being sulfonated again, it could be seen from Fig. 9(c) that the downward trend of the curve was similar to Fig. 9(a), which was mainly caused by the regeneration of the -SO3H groups and silanols during secondary sulfonated. In addition, according to ICP, the content of S before reaction is 4.887%. However, after calcination, sulfuric acid impregnation, centrifugal washing to neutral and drying, the content of S in the catalyst reached 4.723%. This showed that the secondary sulfonated of the catalyst after calcination can well supplement S element to meet the needs of the reaction. In addition to the characterization of the catalyst appearance, Py-FTIR was also carried out on the catalyst after five circulations and sulfonation. As shown in Table 4 , there were no obvious changes in the acid amounts of LA and BA of the catalyst after circulations and sulfonation, which proved that the catalyst had good reusability. 4 Conclusion In this research, a core-shell catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H was synthesized by multi step, which the core provided LA and the shell provided BA. By constructing an interface with internal and external spatial relations, the synergistic effect of double acid sites was maximized, reducing repeated diffusion of intermediates between active sites. Xylose was isomerized to xylulose under the action of LA, and xylulose dehydrated to furfural by BA. It reduced the activation energy and improved the reaction rate, and the highest furfural yield was 70.1%. The WO3@mSiO2-SO3H catalyst showed good stability, after 5 times of recycling, the catalytic activity did not change significantly. It provided a successful case for the preparation of furfural from xylose by core-shell catalyst, and also provided a research basis for the preparation of high value-added derivatives from biomass by core-shell catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A core-shell biacid catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H was prepared. Through the core-shell structure, an interface with internal and external spatial relationship was formed, which was used to synergistic catalyze the preparation of furfural from xylose. And the conversion of xylose was as high as 98.7% and the furfural yield was 70.1% at 170°C for 4 h in water-toluene mixture (1:2 v/v%). The research provided a case for the preparation of furfural from xylose catalyzed by sulfonated core-shell catalyst and provided more application prospects for core-shell catalysts in biomass conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Core-shell catalyst WO3@mSiO2-SO3H interfacial synergy catalyzed the preparation of furfural from xylose
